user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl:
```c
void OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl(osal_objtype_t idtype, uint32 attempts)
{
    OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *impl;
    struct timespec         ts;

    impl = OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype];

    /*
     * because pthread_cond_timedwait() is also a cancellation point,
     * this pushes a cleanup handler to ensure that if canceled during this call,
     * the mutex will be released.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex, &impl->mutex);

    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &ts);

    if (attempts <= 10)
    {
        /* Wait an increasing amount of time, starting at 10ms */
        ts.tv_nsec += attempts * attempts * 10000000;
        if (ts.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
        {
            ts.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
            ++ts.tv_sec;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /* wait 1 second (max for polling) */
        ++ts.tv_sec;
    }

    pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cond, &impl->mutex, &ts);

    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl:

{
    pthread_mutex_t mutex;
    pthread_cond_t  cond;
} OS_impl_objtype_lock_t

void OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex(void *mut)
{
    pthread_mutex_unlock(mut);
}
...

    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR]      = &OS_dir_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE] = &OS_timebase_table_lock,

explanation: I inspected the provided target function and the related code. There are no calls to memcmp (or any other standard library string comparison function) in OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl or in the additional code snippets. The function only manipulates a timespec and calls pthread_cond_timedwait, and the related definitions initialize lock-table pointers and call pthread_mutex_unlock. There is no handling of null-terminated strings, no inclusion or use of string.h functions, and no memory comparisons of character buffers. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
